title: Understanding Vaginal Cancer
subtitle: What it is, why it's done, and what to expect

content.value: Vaginal cancer is a rare cancer that begins in the tissues of the vagina — the muscular canal connecting the cervix to the outside of the body. It often first appears as **pre-cancerous changes (VAIN)**, making early detection essential.

content.description: Most common in women over 60, often linked to HPV infection

content.value: Vaginal cancer starts in the cells lining the surface of the vagina.

items.title: Squamous Cell Carcinoma
items.description: Most common (85-90%). Forms in the thin, flat cells lining the vagina. Often begins as VAIN (vaginal intraepithelial neoplasia).

items.title: Adenocarcinoma
items.description: Develops in gland-like cells of the vagina. Less common but may spread more easily.

content.title: When to Seek Medical Advice
content.description: Seek medical advice for unusual bleeding, persistent discharge, pelvic pain, pain during sex, or a lump inside the vagina.

items: History of cervical cancer or pre-cancer

content.title: Important Note
content.description: Having risk factors does NOT guarantee you will get vaginal cancer. Regular screenings and HPV vaccination help reduce risk.

content.title: Early Detection
content.description: Routine pelvic exams are important for early detection.

steps: Pelvic exam — Visual inspection of the vagina and cervix using a speculum
Pap test — May reveal vaginal cancer cells
Colposcopy — Magnified examination of the vagina using a special instrument
Biopsy — Tissue sample is taken and tested for cancer

content.title: Diagnosis Purpose
content.description: These tests help confirm diagnosis and guide treatment planning.

items.title: Surgery
items.content: Vaginectomy — Removal of part or all of the vagina, with possible reconstruction. Hysterectomy — Removal of the uterus may also be recommended.

items.title: Combination Treatments
items.content: Radiation therapy — Uses targeted energy to destroy cancer cells. Chemotherapy — Uses drugs to kill or slow the growth of cancer cells.

content.title: Treatment Planning
content.description: Treatment depends on the type, stage, whether cancer has spread, and your overall health.

content.title: Why It Matters
content.description: Early detection improves treatment success. Regular check-ups and awareness help identify problems early.

items.text: Early detection significantly improves treatment success
Report unusual bleeding, discharge, or pelvic pain promptly
Awareness of vaginal health is important

content.value: **Staying alert to changes, attending regular check-ups, and seeking medical advice early are key steps to protect your health.**
